awd_titl_txt: Photochemical Reactions of Particulate Mercury Species at the Water-Particle Interface in Aquatic Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, Drs. Yong Cai, Guangliang Liu, and Kevin O'Shea at the Florida International University are funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry to study the reactions of mercury (Hg) that is associated with particles in aquatic environments. These particulate Hg species (pHg) are very common in natural waters, and they are often thought of as unreactive and not very mobile. However, they do react under the influence of sunlight (photochemical reactions) and need to be considered for an accurate description of Hg cycling, especially the air-water exchange of Hg. This project aims to provide a basic understanding of these photochemical reactions and explore the role of pHg in the air-water Hg exchange. The project has a broad range of benefits to research, education, and outreach at a Hispanic Serving Institution. It provides training for PhD and undergraduate students. Underrepresented minority students gain research experience. The curriculum development of the unique Environmental Chemistry-focused PhD track program is being enhanced. The project also promotes public awareness on Hg contamination and health risks. 

Since the aquatic particles are semiconducting and photosensitizing in nature, the investigators focus on the photochemical reactions of pHg involving electron-hole pairs and reactive oxygen species. They define the reaction pathways of pHg phototransformations and quantify the kinetics of photochemical reduction of oxidized Hg species and the oxidation of elemental pHg. They also study the mechanisms related to the pHg photoreactions. Experiments using model iron, titanium, and manganese oxide particles of different band gap energies and field-collected particles are combined with quantum chemistry calculations. The bandgap energies analysis uses spectrometric measurements. Particle chemical composition and optical properties are determined using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The analysis of elemental and oxidized Hg in the dissolved and particulate phases is based on an isotope dilution, purge and trap, thermal desorption, and ICP-MS method. The research is expected to clarify the involvement of pHg species in Hg photochemical transformation and the role in air-water Hg exchange.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Cover

Federal Agency and Organization Element to Which Report is Submitted:

4900

Federal Grant or Other Identifying Number Assigned by Agency:

1905239

Project Title:

Photochemical Reactions of Particulate Mercury Species at the Water-Particle Interface in Aquatic Environments

PD/PI Name:

  • Yong Cai, Principal Investigator
  • Guangliang Liu, Co-Principal Investigator
  • Kevin E O'Shea, Co-Principal Investigator

Recipient Organization:

Florida International University

Project/Grant Period:

08/01/2019 - 07/31/2024

Reporting Period:

08/01/2023 - 07/31/2024

Submitting Official (if other than PD\PI):

N/A

Submission Date:

N/A

Signature of Submitting Official (signature shall be submitted in accordance with agency specific instructions)

N/A


 

This project examines the photochemical reactions of particulate mercury (Hg) species bound by aquatic particles (pHg) during Hg biogeochemical cycling. The major scientific findings include 1) the presence of aquatic particles could enhance photoreduction of divalent Hg (Hg(II)) to produce elemental Hg (Hg(0)), with particle size, composition, and concentration in play; 2) engineered silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) are capable of adsorbing Hg onto the surface, resulting in the reduction of Hg(II) under dark condition and the majority of Hg(0) produced forming amalgam AgNPs; 3) photochemical reactions may prompt the reduction of pHg on AgNPs surface compared to dark condition through photoelectron-involved reduction process, but organic matter coating on the surface of AgNPs could affect the reduction of Hg(II) and the distribution of the produced Hg(0) differently; and 4) particles-involved processes could have broad applications for trace metal detections and decontamination and remediation of toxic metals, and photochemical Hg transformation an important step in regulating Hg biogeochemical cycling and fish Hg bioaccumulation. These findings reveal the occurrence of pHg photochemical transformation, the reaction pathways with photoelectron capable of reducing Hg(II), and the overall effect of pHg transformation on Hg biogeochemical cycling. The research results have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journal publications, manuscripts preparation, and meeting/workshop presentations, with a total of 11 peer-reviewed journal publications and approximately 20 conference and workshop presentations. This project has advanced the field of environmental chemistry, especially in environmental photochemistry. The discovery of the direct involvement of aquatic particles in photoreaction of Hg species in natural waters underscores the importance of inclusion of heterogeneous photochemistry in aquatic chemistry. The results on the interactions of Hg with silver nanoparticles and the associated effect on Hg transformation through adsorption, reduction, and amalgamation processes will expand the traditional environmental chemistry to environmental nanochemistry. This project provides opportunities for training and professional development of one postdoctoral research fellow, six PhD graduate students conducting dissertation research (with three have successfully graduated during the project period), and over ten undergraduate students carrying out independent research. As Florida International University (FIU, the project site) is a Hispanic Serving Institution and has a strong tradition for minority education and research, all the students involved have been from underrepresented groups. This project has greatly enhanced the unique "Environmental chemistry focused PhD track" at FIU. This project has benefited the curriculum development of environmental chemistry program, as the project results have been included in core graduate environmental chemistry courses and the cross-disciplinary teaching of related courses, providing valuable educational resources.


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Guangliang Liu
